physDesc.p: This letter is two pages long. The word Aldington is written in pencil in the top left at a forty-five-degree angle slanting upwards from left to right. The date is in the top right of both pages and the annotation “R.A.--2” is in the top left of the second page.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I enclose a draft for £16-3-2, representing yours and Hilda’s share of the August 1st royalties from our two volumes of “Imagist Poets.” The sales were as follows: 249 Imagist Poets, 1915. .36 1/4 $90.26 389 Imagist Poets, 1916. .36 1/4 [$]141.01 [$]231.27 There are 3 undivided cents, + as I cannot divide them amongst six people, I am keeping them as my commission!!

We are within 35 volumes of as many sold of the 1916 volume as of the 1915 at this date, with the exception of the English sale. Houghton Mifflin are extremely careless, and Constable was either careless or unwilling. Ferris Greenslet says he was away on his vacation; at any rate, I left it to them to arrange with the English house how many copies they would take, and somehow it slipped up and the English house has not ordered any copies yet. I had a talk with Greenslet about it just before I came up here, and he said that their contract with Constable was such that C. must take the book, and that he would see that they did it at once. But of course no sales from them appear on this statement. Houghton Mifflin were very careless about this, and it is awfully annoying, but we are doing the best we can about it now. The book is making a nice little property, as you see, and the fact that the first one is still selling is a very hopeful sign.

I had a nice letter from Hilda the other day. She tells me she is leaving Devonshire to be near you, and that she will let me know her address later. I have not yet received it, so I cannot write to her. She sent me a number of Cournos’ poems, which I sent on to Braithwaite. Whether he will take them or not I do not know. Between you and me and the gate-post, I am not much struck with them, and I think there is very little chance of my being able to place them, but I will do my best.

There is nothing new. This is a peaceful place and very little happens here. I am engaged on the proof-sheets of “Men, Women and Ghosts” which will come out in October, and also my lectures on modern poets. My “Craftsman” article has met with quite a little success. I am sending a copy of it to you.
Will write again soon, and with love to Hilda when you see her, believe me,

div.note: Amy Lowell, "Is There a National Spirit in 'The New Poetry' of America?" The Craftsman, Vol. 30, No. 4 (July, 1916), pp. 39-49.
